metadata.titleEn: Multi-scale surface flux and meteorological elements observation dataset in the Hai River Basin (Huailai station-eddy covariance system-40m tower, 2018)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the Huailai station eddy covariance system (EC) from January 1 to December 31 in 2018. The site (115.7923° E, 40.3574°N) was located in the maize surface, near Donghuayuan town of Huailai city in Hebei Province. The elevation is 480 m. The EC was installed at a height of 3.5 m, and the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (CSAT3&EC150) was 0 m.
The raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Eddypro post-processing software, including the spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. The observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC): class 1 (level 0: Δst<30 and ITC<30), class 2 (level 1: Δst<100 and ITC<100), and class 3 (level 2: Δst>100 and ITC>100), which represent high-, medium-, and low-quality data, respectively. In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data collected before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 10% of the 30 min raw record; and (4) data were rejected at night when the friction velocity (u*) was less than 0.1 m/s. There were 48 records per day, and the missing data were replaced with -6999. Suspicious data were marked in red. There were lots of negative values of H2O density in winter where filling by -6999.
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (z/L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xls format. Detailed information can be found in the suggested references.
For more information, please refer to Guo et al. (2020) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2013) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is a key factor in surface flux estimations with remote sensing algorithms and/or land surface models. Originally, z0m is defined as the height where the wind speed, given by the extrapolation of the logarithmic wind profile, becomes zero. According to numerous observations, the variation range of z0m over different surfaces is large, from an order of 1.0 m over urban areas and mountainous areas, to an order of 0.1 mm or even 0.01 mm over smooth water body surfaces, ice and snow surfaces. The traditional way to calculate z0m is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory, using wind profile measurements. In practical applications, especially for remote sensing models and land surface models, it is difficult to obtain z0m for a local or regional scale based only on station observations. Former researchers have proposed some parameterizations between the aerodynamic roughness length and the land surface properties [e.g., vegetation height, leaf area index (LAI), etc.], since wind turbulence is controlled by the structure and spacing of roughness elements (plants and other obstacles) on the land surface, and z0m describes the roughness characteristics of a surface.
research objective: Based on the data of the Xiaotangshan Experiment (Changping District of Beijing, China), which was conducted in 2002, 2004, and 2005 respectively, the objectives of this paper are: (1) to calculate z0m over different surfaces and analyze the directional characteristics of z0m over heterogeneous surfaces using an analytical footprint model; (2) to relate the estimated z0m over heterogeneous surfaces to roughness element characteristic factors, and present a heuristic parameterization of z0m as a reference for model parameterizations.
challenges: More data is needed for further discussions.
methods: This paper calculates z0m over several land surfaces, with 3 years of experimental data from Xiaotangshan. Individual z0m over each surface component (patch) is calculated firstly with the characteristic parameters of the roughness elements (vegetation height, leaf area index, etc.), then z0m over the whole experimental field is aggregated, using the footprint weighting method.
dataset: This experiment was carried out at the Xiaotangshan Experimental Station for Precision Agriculture (40°10′41′′N, 116°26′52′′E, 35 m above sea level) in Beijing. The observation period in 2002 was from 26 March to 23 April and the land cover was bare soil. In 2004, the experiment was carried out from 30 May to 7 July. In the southern sub-plot field, the land cover was bare soil between 30 May and 11 June, while the maize plants started emerging around 12 June. In 2005, the experiment was from 1 May to 10 June and the experimental layout was almost the same as that in 2004.
findings: The results show that z0m is direction-dependent, mainly due to the heterogeneity of the size and spatial distribution of the roughness elements inside the source area along different wind directions.

background: For surface flux measurements, large aperture scintillometer (LAS) has become more and more popular in recent years. Compared with traditional observation techniques, it can measure surface fluxes on a larger scale (500 m to 10 km). At present, LAS observation is not common in China.
research objective: The daily and monthly variation of HLAS is analyzed. And the observation differences between eddy covariance system and LAS, need to be studied further combined with footprint model and energy unbalance of eddy covariance system observation.
challenges: There is much less agreement on the form which universal stability function fT should take. Further more, since the iteration process of HLAS can not be convergence when low wind speed and very stable conditions appearing at night, Wm \ - 5 is specified.
findings: Sensible heat flux (H) calculation with the LAS data of above measurements shows that the beam height of LAS and wind speed are sensitive factors for sensible heat flux measurement (HLAS), zero-plane displacement height is crucial unless the beam height is much larger than it, and Bowen ratio needs to be determined accurately over wet surface, while air temperature, air pressure and aerodynamic roughness length are not sensitive for HLAS. According to the observations mentioned above, LAS can measure surface fluxes both over homogeneous and heterogeneous surfaces.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a dataset that uses Eddypro software for post-processing eddy covariance data, and describe the typical steps involved in this process?
Example.Answer: A dataset that uses Eddypro software for post-processing eddy covariance data involves steps such as despiking, time lag correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, sonic virtual temperature correction, and density (WPL) correction. The quality of flux values is evaluated based on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics.

Example.Question: What is an example of a research approach used to calculate aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over heterogeneous surfaces, and how are roughness element characteristics considered?
Example.Answer: A research approach to calculate aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over heterogeneous surfaces involves using an analytical footprint model to relate estimated z0m to roughness element characteristics like vegetation height and leaf area index. Individual z0m for each surface component is calculated first, then aggregated using footprint weighting.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of challenges faced when using large aperture scintillometer (LAS) for surface flux measurements, and how these challenges might be addressed?
Example.Answer: An example of challenges faced when using LAS for surface flux measurements includes issues with the universal stability function fT, particularly under low wind speed and stable conditions at night, which can prevent iteration convergence. Addressing these challenges requires specifying conditions such as Wm \ - 5 and ensuring accurate determination of factors like zero-plane displacement height and Bowen ratio.

Definition.Question: How is the aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) calculated in surface flux estimation models?
Definition.Answer: The aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is calculated based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory using wind profile measurements. In models, z0m is often parameterized with land surface properties such as vegetation height and leaf area index, since it describes the roughness characteristics of a surface. The calculation over heterogeneous surfaces can involve the use of analytical footprint models to relate z0m to roughness element characteristics.

Comparison.Question: How do data collection methods using eddy covariance systems compare to those using large aperture scintillometers in terms of spatial coverage and measurement capabilities?
Comparison.Answer: Eddy covariance systems typically measure surface fluxes at a localized point scale, whereas large aperture scintillometers (LAS) can measure surface fluxes over larger distances (500 m to 10 km). LAS observations provide broader spatial coverage compared to the point measurements of eddy covariance systems.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data processing and quality control steps between datasets obtained from eddy covariance systems and those collected from aerodynamic roughness length experiments?
Comparison.Answer: Data from eddy covariance systems go through extensive processing, including wild point removal, delay time correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, and various flux quality assessments. In contrast, aerodynamic roughness length experiments involve calculating z0m using wind profile measurements and footprint models, focusing on parameterization related to land surface properties.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges faced in estimating surface fluxes with eddy covariance systems differ from those encountered using large aperture scintillometers?
Comparison.Answer: Eddy covariance systems face challenges related to the accuracy of flux measurements under low turbulence conditions and the need for quality control of flux data. In contrast, large aperture scintillometers encounter issues with beam height sensitivity, zero-plane displacement height, and convergence during low wind speed and stable atmospheric conditions at night.

Interpretation.Question: How can the quality assessment criteria used in the data processing, such as atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics, affect the interpretation of surface flux measurements in different environmental conditions?
Interpretation.Answer: The quality assessment criteria based on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics help ensure that the data reflects accurate environmental conditions. By categorizing the data into different quality levels based on these factors, researchers can better interpret the reliability of surface flux measurements under various conditions, such as different times of day or weather patterns, which influence atmospheric stability and turbulence.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the complexity of accurately estimating aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over heterogeneous surfaces?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The complexity arises from the large variation range of z0m over different surfaces and its direction-dependent characteristics due to the heterogeneity of the size and spatial distribution of roughness elements inside the source area along different wind directions. Additionally, the traditional method of calculating z0m using Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory requires detailed wind profile measurements, which are challenging to obtain at local or regional scales.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What challenges are associated with using large aperture scintillometer (LAS) for measuring surface fluxes, particularly in terms of data reliability and accuracy?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges include the sensitivity of sensible heat flux measurements to beam height and wind speed, the critical importance of accurately determining zero-plane displacement height unless the beam height is much larger, and the accurate determination of Bowen ratio over wet surfaces. Additionally, there is less agreement on the form of the universal stability function fT, and the iteration process for HLAS may not converge under low wind speeds and stable night conditions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might there be difficulties in obtaining consistent surface flux estimations from remote sensing models and land surface models?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Difficulties arise because remote sensing models and land surface models find it challenging to obtain local or regional scale aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) only from station observations. This is due to the variability in z0m across different surfaces, from urban to smooth water bodies, and the lack of detailed wind profile measurements needed for traditional z0m calculations. Parameterizations between z0m and land surface properties, like vegetation height and leaf area index, are necessary but complex to implement accurately.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using different methods to calculate aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) on the accuracy of surface flux estimations?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using different methods to calculate aerodynamic roughness length (z0m), such as the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory or heuristic parameterizations, can significantly affect the accuracy of surface flux estimations. Accurate z0m calculations are crucial as they influence the representation of surface roughness in models, impacting the estimation of wind and flux characteristics over various land surfaces.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary goal of utilizing eddy covariance systems for measuring surface fluxes in the context of multi-scale observation datasets?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goal of utilizing eddy covariance systems in multi-scale observation datasets is to accurately measure surface fluxes such as sensible heat, latent heat, and CO2 fluxes, with a focus on understanding atmospheric stability and turbulence characteristics. This involves processing high-frequency data to provide insights into the interactions between the land surface and the atmosphere, and ensuring the quality and reliability of the flux data through various corrections and quality assessments.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to explore the aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over different surfaces using data from experiments like the Xiaotangshan Experiment?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important to explore the aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over different surfaces because z0m is a critical factor in estimating surface fluxes and understanding the interaction between the atmosphere and the land surface. The goal is to relate z0m to roughness element characteristics, such as vegetation height and leaf area index, and to develop parameterizations that can be used in remote sensing and land surface models for accurate flux estimations over heterogeneous surfaces.

Goal Orientation.Question: What motivates the use of large aperture scintillometer (LAS) for surface flux measurements and how does it compare to traditional observation techniques?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The motivation for using large aperture scintillometer (LAS) for surface flux measurements lies in its ability to measure fluxes over larger spatial scales, ranging from 500 m to 10 km, compared to traditional techniques. The goal is to address the challenges of data unbalance and measurement differences with eddy covariance systems, while capturing sensible heat flux over both homogeneous and heterogeneous surfaces. This approach seeks to refine flux estimations and enhance the understanding of spatial variability in energy exchanges.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in processing raw data from eddy covariance systems to generate usable flux datasets?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The raw data from eddy covariance systems is processed using software like Eddypro. The steps include outlier removal, time delay correction, coordinate rotation (secondary coordinate rotation), frequency response correction, sonic virtual temperature correction, and density corrections (WPL). Quality evaluation of the flux values is also conducted, primarily examining atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can large aperture scintillometers be used to measure surface fluxes, and what challenges might arise during the data collection process?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Large aperture scintillometers can measure surface fluxes over large scales, from 500 m to 10 km. Challenges in using these instruments include achieving convergence in low wind speed and stable conditions at night, determining the beam height relative to zero-plane displacement height, and accurately measuring the Bowen ratio over wet surfaces.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods can be used to estimate the aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over heterogeneous surfaces, and how is directional dependence accounted for?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over heterogeneous surfaces can be estimated using an analytical footprint model. The z0m is calculated for each surface component based on the characteristics of roughness elements like vegetation height and leaf area index, and then aggregated using the footprint weighting method. Directional dependence is accounted for by considering the heterogeneity of the size and spatial distribution of roughness elements along different wind directions.

Enablement.Question: What data processing techniques enable the transformation of raw high-frequency measurements into usable surface flux datasets?
Enablement.Answer: The transformation of raw high-frequency measurements into usable surface flux datasets is enabled by data processing techniques such as Eddypro software for post-processing. Key steps include outlier removal, time lag correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density correction. Quality evaluations such as atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity tests are also conducted to ensure data quality.

Enablement.Question: How does the selection of measurement instruments and their configuration enable accurate collection of surface flux data in heterogeneous landscapes?
Enablement.Answer: The accurate collection of surface flux data in heterogeneous landscapes is enabled by using instruments like eddy covariance systems, which are configured with specific parameters such as sampling frequency (10Hz) and ultrasonic anemometer orientation. The precise placement and alignment of instruments, such as setting the sonic anemometer facing true north and ensuring zero distance between key components, contribute to the accuracy of the data collected.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be a discrepancy between surface flux measurements obtained using eddy covariance systems and large aperture scintillometers?
Expectation.Answer: The discrepancy could be due to differences in the scales at which these instruments measure surface fluxes, as LAS can measure over larger areas compared to eddy covariance systems. Additionally, the energy unbalance in eddy covariance system observations and the challenges in the convergence of HLAS calculations during low wind speed and stable conditions at night might contribute to measurement differences.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be an expectation for more data in the analysis of aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over heterogeneous surfaces?
Expectation.Answer: More data is needed to thoroughly understand the directional characteristics and spatial variability of z0m over heterogeneous surfaces. The complex interaction between atmospheric conditions and the structural features of roughness elements, like vegetation height and distribution, requires extensive datasets to develop accurate heuristic parameterizations and improve model parameterizations.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using an eddy covariance system for measuring surface fluxes in heterogeneous land surfaces?
Judgmental.Answer: The eddy covariance system is effective for measuring surface fluxes, especially when combined with data post-processing techniques such as quality assessment and corrections for atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity. However, the system's effectiveness may be challenged by night-time weak turbulence and data gaps due to factors like power issues, as seen in the provided data.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the techniques used to estimate aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) and how these contribute to understanding surface flux estimations.
Request/Directive.Answer: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is estimated using Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory and is influenced by wind profile measurements. The estimation involves calculating z0m over different surfaces using roughness element characteristics like vegetation height and leaf area index. The footprint weighting method aggregates z0m over an experimental field. Understanding z0m is crucial for surface flux estimations as it describes surface roughness, which affects wind turbulence and is necessary for remote sensing and land surface models.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential datasets or experimental setups that could enhance the measurement of surface fluxes over heterogeneous landscapes.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets could include those obtained from the Xiaotangshan Experiment, which involved measurements over several years with varying land covers, including bare soil and maize fields. These datasets could improve understanding of surface fluxes over heterogeneous landscapes by providing data on different surface components and using footprint weighting methods. Experimental setups should consider using large aperture scintillometers (LAS) to measure fluxes over larger scales and in diverse conditions to enhance data collection and analysis.
